pullrequest.title: Prevent GUI from jumping around, pixel saving, analysis submission improvements

content.raw:
Since this change touches a fair bit of the GUI, I'm eager to get it merged sometime in the next week, because after that I'm going away for three weeks, and any changes people make in the meantime will surely clash.

I've made my other pull request about the shot deletion compatible with this one, but in any case it can wait. Since it's a plugin it is relatively unaffected by other changes and so will merge easily later even if there are other changes and I take a holiday (hooray for [Conway's law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conway%27s_law)). And as I said I'm happy for that to wait until there's a GUI for enabling/disabling plugins.

This one the most substantial logic changes are to the analysis submission. I've tested it a fair bit, but nonetheless it's the highest risk part of the changes, the rest is just moving GUI things around.

And as I said I'm happy for that to wait until there's a GUI for enabling/disabling plugins.

This one the most substantial logic changes are to the analysis submission. I've tested it a fair bit, but nonetheless it's the highest risk part of the changes, the rest is just moving GUI things around.

pullrequest.title: Prevent GUI from jumping around, pixel saving, analysis submission improvements

content.html:
@shaunj will need to be the one who tests a lot of this, but things I can see so far:

  • Some of the queue manager status messages have lost information. In my view that information was useful (for example: if you're not watching the experiment, it is useful to know whether the hardware failed mid experiment or during programming).
  • The code that loads shots into the queue after clicking the button should a) accept files with extension .hdf5 and b) actually confirm the filepaths end with .h5 and .hdf5 since Qt actually fails completely at doing that check, even though it's specified. See the 10 or so lines starting here

pullrequest.title: Prevent GUI from jumping around, pixel saving, analysis submission improvements

content.raw:
OK, I'm testing this now, seems fine so far.
I agree that it's usually helpful to know at what stage the experiment crashed.
content.html: OK, I'm testing this now, seems fine so far. I agree that it's usually helpful to know at what stage the experiment crashed.

pullrequest.title: Prevent GUI from jumping around, pixel saving, analysis submission improvements

content.raw:
Ah good point about the error messages. I'll put the extra detail back in then, with manual linebreaks to make it not be likely to elide. The elision still works with multiline, it just puts the "..." in themiddle of one side rather than next to the actual lines of text. The GUI will still jump as the label grows in size, but since the queue will be paused it will stay there until the user does something, so that's fine I think. Another alternative is to grow an error pulldown thing like that tabs have.

Ok, thanks for the points about h5 and hdf5! Rep-generating code assumes the files end with .h5 though, and not hdf5. As does a lot of code elsewhere I think. So if I make it accept .hdf5 as well as .h5, then problems will still come up if files end in .hdf5. Shot files are (most of the time) generally generated by runmanager, which imposes .h5, but the user could still make a file that doesn't end in that. Should we just make it error on files that don't end in .h5? "sorry, I know it's an hdf5 file but we need to be able to make assumptions about extensions, please make your files end in .h5"

Thanks for the comments, and thanks for the testing Shaun!
content.html:
Ah good point about the error messages. I'll put the extra detail back in then, with manual linebreaks to make it not be likely to elide. The elision still works with multiline, it just puts the "..." in themiddle of one side rather than next to the actual lines of text. The GUI will still jump as the label grows in size, but since the queue will be paused it will stay there until the user does something, so that's fine I think. Another alternative is to grow an error pulldown thing like that tabs have.

Ok, thanks for the points about h5 and hdf5! Rep-generating code assumes the files end with .h5 though, and not hdf5. As does a lot of code elsewhere I think. So if I make it accept .hdf5 as well as .h5, then problems will still come up if files end in .hdf5. Shot files are (most of the time) generally generated by runmanager, which imposes .h5, but the user could still make a file that doesn't end in that. Should we just make it error on files that don't end in .h5? "sorry, I know it's an hdf5 file but we need to be able to make assumptions about extensions, please make your files end in .h5"

Thanks for the comments, and thanks for the testing Shaun!

pullrequest.title: Prevent GUI from jumping around, pixel saving, analysis submission improvements

content.raw:
This could be because even though the `zmq_get` call times out, the contents of the submitted packet are actually sitting in a buffer in lyse, and eventually get read. Likely happens because the lyse zmq server is being blocked by running analysis and not being responsive?

I've seen something similar when launching runviewer from runmanager. The submission to runviewer fails, but then runviewer starts after the timeout and has loaded the shot correctly.
content.html:
This could be because even though the zmq_get call times out, the contents of the submitted packet are actually sitting in a buffer in lyse, and eventually get read. Likely happens because the lyse zmq server is being blocked by running analysis and not being responsive?

I've seen something similar when launching runviewer from runmanager. The submission to runviewer fails, but then runviewer starts after the timeout and has loaded the shot correctly.

pullrequest.title: Prevent GUI from jumping around, pixel saving, analysis submission improvements

content.raw:
Aha, found it! A single character bug.

In the mainloop of the analysis submission, it waits for signals for what to do, and if that times out after 10 seconds it instead sets signal to 'check/retry' to check connectivity.

However I had written `signal == 'check/retry'` instead of `signal = 'check/retry'`. Meaning that line did nothing and instead the signal from the last iteration of the mainloop was processed again (submitting the shot file again).

I've pushed the fix.
content.html:
Aha, found it! A single character bug.

In the mainloop of the analysis submission, it waits for signals for what to do, and if that times out after 10 seconds it instead sets signal to 'check/retry' to check connectivity.

However I had written signal == 'check/retry' instead of signal = 'check/retry'. Meaning that line did nothing and instead the signal from the last iteration of the mainloop was processed again (submitting the shot file again).

I've pushed the fix.

pullrequest.title: Prevent GUI from jumping around, pixel saving, analysis submission improvements

content.raw: That's better :)
content.html: That's better :)

pullrequest.title: Prevent GUI from jumping around, pixel saving, analysis submission improvements

content.raw:
Aah, I see. That seems likely!

Lyse's zmq server probably isn't blocked by analysis running, but reading h5 files. h5py holds the GIL. This used to cause > 1 second delays  with heartbeating, and we had to switch to doing heartbeating without the parent touching the Python interpreter, so it could respond quickly.

I guess I'd better increase the timeout again, perhaps even 3 seconds is better. 

Resolving issue #22 in the way being discussed in the thread there might solve this, as it would relieve the lyse process from having to read h5 files a lot of the time. Nothing else we use holds the GIL like that. Perhaps also we should make it that lyse can receive a list of shots all in one zmq request, so that reading one h5 file doesn't block it from receiving the next one.
content.html:
Aah, I see. That seems likely!

Lyse's zmq server probably isn't blocked by analysis running, but reading h5 files. h5py holds the GIL. This used to cause > 1 second delays with heartbeating, and we had to switch to doing heartbeating without the parent touching the Python interpreter, so it could respond quickly.

I guess I'd better increase the timeout again, perhaps even 3 seconds is better.

Resolving issue #22 in the way being discussed in the thread there might solve this, as it would relieve the lyse process from having to read h5 files a lot of the time. Nothing else we use holds the GIL like that. Perhaps also we should make it that lyse can receive a list of shots all in one zmq request, so that reading one h5 file doesn't block it from receiving the next one.

pullrequest.title: Prevent GUI from jumping around, pixel saving, analysis submission improvements

content.raw:
So It looks like you get that error *as well* as everything continuing to function, right?

It looks like I mistook a bit of code for "this is a catch-all exception handler for if something goes wrong that was unexpected", when the code was actually being used to catch more expected errors.

An exception is raised earlier in order to intentionally trigger the cleanup code. At least there is a comment acknowledging that it's dodgy! It's essentially using the exception as a GOTO.

I could remove the error popup (it is just for visibility so you don't miss the tracebacks from actual unexpected crashes) but I think I can easily refactor to remove the dodgy exception.
content.html:
So It looks like you get that error as well as everything continuing to function, right?

It looks like I mistook a bit of code for "this is a catch-all exception handler for if something goes wrong that was unexpected", when the code was actually being used to catch more expected errors.

An exception is raised earlier in order to intentionally trigger the cleanup code. At least there is a comment acknowledging that it's dodgy! It's essentially using the exception as a GOTO.

I could remove the error popup (it is just for visibility so you don't miss the tracebacks from actual unexpected crashes) but I think I can easily refactor to remove the dodgy exception.

pullrequest.title: Prevent GUI from jumping around, pixel saving, analysis submission improvements
Prevent GUI from jumping around, pixel saving, analysis submission improvements

content.raw:
I pushed a fix. Pretty simple:


```
#!diff

--- a/queue.py	Mon Jun 19 14:29:52 2017 -0400
+++ b/queue.py	Tue Jun 20 00:42:29 2017 -0400
@@ -801,25 +801,25 @@
                         error_condition = True
                     if self.get_device_error_state(device_name,devices_in_use):
                         error_condition = True
                     # Once device has transitioned_to_manual, disconnect restart signal
                     inmain(tab.disconnect_restart_receiver,restart_function)
                     
                 if error_condition:                
                     self.set_status("Error in transtion to manual\nQueue Paused")
-                    # TODO: Kind of dodgy raising an exception here...
-                    raise Exception('A device failed during transition to manual')
                                        
             except Exception as e:
+                error_condition = True
                 logger.exception("Error in queue manager execution. Queue paused.")
 
                 # Raise the error in a thread for visibility
                 zprocess.raise_exception_in_thread(sys.exc_info())
                 
+            if error_condition:
                 # clean up the h5 file
                 self.manager_paused = True
                 # clean the h5 file:
                 self.clean_h5_file(path, 'temp.h5')
                 try:
                     os.remove(path)
                     os.rename('temp.h5', path)
                 except WindowsError if platform.system() == 'Windows' else None:
```
content.html:
I pushed a fix. Pretty simple:

--- a/queue.py  Mon Jun 19 14:29:52 2017 -0400
+++ b/queue.py  Tue Jun 20 00:42:29 2017 -0400
@@ -801,25 +801,25 @@
                         error_condition = True
                     if self.get_device_error_state(device_name,devices_in_use):
                         error_condition = True
                     # Once device has transitioned_to_manual, disconnect restart signal
                     inmain(tab.disconnect_restart_receiver,restart_function)

                 if error_condition:                
                     self.set_status("Error in transtion to manual\nQueue Paused")
-                    # TODO: Kind of dodgy raising an exception here...
-                    raise Exception('A device failed during transition to manual')

             except Exception as e:
+                error_condition = True
                 logger.exception("Error in queue manager execution. Queue paused.")

                 # Raise the error in a thread for visibility
                 zprocess.raise_exception_in_thread(sys.exc_info())

+            if error_condition:
                 # clean up the h5 file
                 self.manager_paused = True
                 # clean the h5 file:
                 self.clean_h5_file(path, 'temp.h5')
                 try:
                     os.remove(path)
                     os.rename('temp.h5', path)
                 except WindowsError if platform.system() == 'Windows' else None:

pullrequest.title: Prevent GUI from jumping around, pixel saving, analysis submission improvements

content.raw:
Here are a few more general comments on some of the changes in this pull request:

* I can't actually find any error messages that need eliding, the queue width is limited by the control buttons first, if I make it any smaller than them the whole thing is hidden. This means that I can't test the multi-line stuff.

* I think that the status bars on tabs may be slightly too narrow now, they look a bit weird without some extra whitespace above the text.

* Not really related to changes made here, but the interface in general, it looks as though various borders look different on our computer compared with yours. In Windows, the border around the tab itself is quite light compared with the border around the tab contents. This makes it less obvious that the status bar is part of the tab. Do you think that it is worth altering these while we're changing other aspects of the interface? See attached screenshot compared with the one on the pull request

![blacs borders.PNG](data/bitbucket.org/repo/dR5qxr/images/4064635204-blacs_borders.PNG)
content.html:
Here are a few more general comments on some of the changes in this pull request:

  • I can't actually find any error messages that need eliding, the queue width is limited by the control buttons first, if I make it any smaller than them the whole thing is hidden. This means that I can't test the multi-line stuff.

  • I think that the status bars on tabs may be slightly too narrow now, they look a bit weird without some extra whitespace above the text.

  • Not really related to changes made here, but the interface in general, it looks as though various borders look different on our computer compared with yours. In Windows, the border around the tab itself is quite light compared with the border around the tab contents. This makes it less obvious that the status bar is part of the tab. Do you think that it is worth altering these while we're changing other aspects of the interface? See attached screenshot compared with the one on the pull request

pullrequest.title: Prevent GUI from jumping around, pixel saving, analysis submission improvements

content.raw:
I'd like to have the following addressed before we merge this:

* I still can't work out what you've done to make the status bars smaller than they used to be, it seems to be overriding the margin when I try to increase it. It just needs a few extra pixels of vertical space.

* While doing all of this pixel saving, you should also shrink the gaps between each tab frame (approx half the current size would probably do).

* It's not always immediately obvious what the "connection" is now that it's in the brackets after the device name. Sometimes it's just an integer, sometimes an ip address, or sometimes a string (in our lab, the NI card connections have the same name as the device). Perhaps you should write "**Device_name** [Conn: conection_string]" to make is slightly more obvious?

content.raw:
- I can add some pixels! I think it was about the margins of the layout it's in rather than the widget itself.

- Will halve the splitter handle width. I actually increased it to 12 pixels up from 6, but you're right, that's pretty big : 6 is the default size of most gaps between things that aren't intentionally closer.

- Sounds good about the connection string - now that the text is elided it's not so important that it's as short as possible anyway.

  • Will halve the splitter handle width. I actually increased it to 12 pixels up from 6, but you're right, that's pretty big : 6 is the default size of most gaps between things that aren't intentionally closer.

  • Sounds good about the connection string - now that the text is elided it's not so important that it's as short as possible anyway.

pullrequest.title: Prevent GUI from jumping around, pixel saving, analysis submission improvements

content.raw:
Yes, the splitter handles were 12 and now they're 6. But there were also margins on each tab widget, which were 9. So I've just changed them to 3.

So spacing between tab widgets before = 9 + 12 + 9 = 30

Spacing now: = 3 + 6 + 3 = 12

So closer to "half" as suggested.
content.html:
Yes, the splitter handles were 12 and now they're 6. But there were also margins on each tab widget, which were 9. So I've just changed them to 3.

So spacing between tab widgets before = 9 + 12 + 9 = 30

Spacing now: = 3 + 6 + 3 = 12

So closer to "half" as suggested.
